Dear ##SM_RULE_360 Email Salutation##,

Recent headlines and graphic photos reveal that young women incarcerated in the Geneva Youth Rehabilitation Center were being housed in inhumane and unsafe conditions. Sadly, these are not isolated incidents. The most recently available data analysis about juvenile solitary in Nebraska shows the average length of juvenile solitary confinement is 25.5 hours and though people of color represent about 4 out of 20 Nebraskans, 14 in 20 incidents of juvenile room confinement involve children of color.

The consensus among mental health professionals is clear: we should not use isolation of juveniles except when absolutely necessary, and then only for extremely short periods with active engagement between youth and mental health professionals to address the crisis. We can and we must do better for our children. Kids need human interaction, love, health care, family, sunlight, exercise, educational opportunity, and adequate nutrition. Nebraska kids donâ€™t need solitary confinement.

Sign Petition

The ACLU is committed to challenging the criminalization and incarceration of young people and actively working to dismantle racial injustice inherent in these systems. As part of our efforts to reform the juvenile justice system, we are working to end the use of solitary confinement for all young people in juvenile facilities and adult jails and prisons. The good news is that a comprehensive solution that ends these human rights abuses and that is grounded in best practices is perfectly poised to move quickly in the 2020 legislative session. Senator Pansing Brooks introduced LB 230 in 2019 that was advanced with strong support across the political spectrum by the Judiciary Committee to the full body and is presently on General File. This critical reform legislation is a critical first step to ending juvenile solitary as we know it in Nebraska.

Tell your State Senator to end juvenile solitary as the first order of business in the 2020 legislative session.

As Dylan Murphy, a juvenile solitary survivor wrote in a powerful editorial and legislative testimony, "You can leave solitary, but solitary confinement does not leave you. If the youth in our juvenile facilities are to be supported rather than disregarded, then facilities should avoid isolating them at all costs." Please take action today — tell the Nebraska Legislature to support LB 230 as a first order of business in 2020 and end solitary for vulnerable Nebraska children.

Sincerely,

Danielle Conrad
Executive Director, ACLU of Nebraska
